request_pathways.name: Authorization to Release and/or Obtain Patient Information

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients use a generic ROI authorization form for all record requests, with online portals (Swellbox and MyChart) available as alternatives for different date ranges.

red_flags: Email restriction mischaracterizes HIPAA — states records cannot be emailed to anyone but the patient's personal email, contradicting 45 CFR § 164.524(c)(3)(ii) which allows patients to direct records to third parties
Stale form revision (Jan 2019) may not reflect current workflows after Sept 2024 system transition
bright_spots: Multiple access pathways clearly presented on Medical Records page (Swellbox, MyChart, PDF)
Unusually clear plain-language disclosures about limits of protection after release

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation — the form is directly linked from the Medical Records department page, found on the second search attempt with no bot-blocking or deep navigation required.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Usable digitally with workarounds and fax submission available — the PDF has zero fillable fields requiring print-and-handwrite, but fax submission (303-449-9380) provides an electronic submission pathway; online portals exist but were not evaluated.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Adequate but has notable problems — single-page layout is logically organized, but the confusing dual-direction request design, dense authorization block, and limited record type options create clarity issues.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the generic ROI form treats all requests identically with no differentiation between patient self-access and third-party release, and the dual-direction entity routing confuses patients requesting their own records.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Some requirements that may go beyond what the law requires — the email restriction mischaracterizes HIPAA by framing a policy choice as a legal mandate, and fee disclosure is vague with no schedule, though the no-conditioning clause and reasonable expiration are properly included.

overall.summary: Boulder Medical Center provides an easily findable but generic, non-fillable ROI authorization form that does not differentiate patient self-access from third-party release, with a misleading HIPAA email restriction partially offset by multiple access pathways and clear plain-language disclosures.
